text: [Music]
I don't really have too many musician
friends uh most of the musicians I know
have day jobs you know so they they play
music at night and they'd love to get a
record deal but because the I mean the
record companies are all falling
apart most people have been it's it's
forced people to approach a more DIY or
to take a more DIY approach uh where the
musicians I know they're they're
starting their own record companies
they're releasing things online they're
getting friends of theirs to do
publicity there you know it's people
becoming a lot more self-reliant and a
lot more autonomous which I think is
great um I mean because the record
companies aren't going to be around in
five years you know or at least they're
not going to be around in anything
resembling the form that they've had for
the last 50 years so it's it's a
frightening time for a lot of people but
I know this sounds cliche but it's also
a really exciting time and I think music
is benefit you know the actual quality
of music has been a lot better because a
lot of people are putting out records
purely for the love of putting out
records and not hoping to sell millions
of copies because no one sells millions
of copies so the rise of like the indie
rock scene well independent music in
general I think it's been really good
for music creatively and it's also you
know it's
turned the music world world into more
of like a Scandinavian country as
opposed to a South American country
meaning you know if you look at like
Paraguay in the 1970s all the wealth was
concentrated in like 0.1% of the
population and everybody else was poor
and that's kind or you look at Sweden
where it was sort of like the wealth was
distributed evenly among most of the
people in the country and the music
business up until recently was like
Paraguay in the 70s where you had
0.001% of the musicians on the planet
selling tens of millions of records and
all the other musicians are sort of like
you know struggling to try and get the
attention of a record company and what's
happened now is you have a lot of
musicians a lot of DJs who are selling
10,000 records here 50,000 records there
and they can make a living you know
they're not getting rich but they're
doing relatively okay I personally think
I mean the demise of the record business
is almost if if you have to point blame
anywhere sadly it's at the record
companies themselves you know because in
the 80s and '90s they kept charging more
and more for CDs even as the even as the
costs came down you know so it's almost
like the record labels would arbitrarily
just keep charging more and more and
they were signing bands who had a shelf
life of about six months so there's no
loyalty you know people were buying CDs
in the 90s because they liked a song
they'd heard on the radio but they could
care less about the artist and so the
labels weren't doing artist development
and as a result there was no loyalty
engendered and so when the record
companies fell apart most
listeners you know it's hard to get too
upset for record companies falling apart
when they've treated artists terribly
for so long and treated consumers
terribly for so
long
